title: Double-click to open me!
contents:
Excellent work!

Now you can see the content in this document!
To close a document, double-click the teal title again.

title: Click and drag me!
contents:
Yep, documents can be moved around!

Move similar documents together so you can think about them as a group.
Resize this document by dragging an open document's edge. Only open documents can be resized.

title: Try writing something down!
contents:
You should see a yellow 'Personal Notebook' document. Try typing 'hello world' into this document!

You can also copy and paste information directly into notes!

title: More notes, anyone?
contents:
By now, you might notice that the interface can get a bit messy. You can create more notes to help organize your thoughts!
Try making a new note: Right-click in the orange background and select 'New note.'
This gives you more space to write things down.
Notes cannot be deleted or renamed, but consider how you could use them to separate different kinds of information or label groups of documents.

title: Highlighting helps!
contents:
In the last document, you used the context menu to create a new note!
The context menu is different when you right-click in documents. In documents, you can:
(1) search for selected text or (2) highlight text.

Let's try highlighting first. Use your cursor to select the following words:

Please select me with your cursor.

With the text selected,
right-click (and hold) and select 'Highlight' in the menu.
The text should now have a green background.

This highlight will appear any time the document is open, so it can be a good way to track what you've already read.

title: Use search! There's too much to read!
contents:
There are two ways to search:
  1. Search by selection: Select text (as you did when highlighting) and choose the option in the context menu. This is helpful for looking into suspicious terms while reading.
  2. Search by query: Right-click in the orange background and type a query into the context menu. Press Enter to see results.


Try searching for the term 'document,' then try querying your own term.

Regardless of how you search, documents with a matching string will now have yellow in their title.

Search is case-insensitive and will only returns exact matches. If you don't get the results you expect, try changing your search term slightly.

title: Not enough time? Don't go random!
contents: You won't have time to read all the documents! Stick to your plan. Use more searches to find connections between people, places, objects, or events that look promising or suspicious.

title: So many approaches!
contents:
Use whichever features help you with the investigation.

We recommend searching for information instead of trying to read everything.
By the way, the background is orange because mysteries often include red herrings. A herring is a type of fish. The fish most similar in color to the University of Florida brand is a salmon. Spotted salmonfish are typically orange and teal.

title: Final notes
contents:
Now you're an expert! (at least with this interface tool)
üñ•Ô∏è Maximize your screen for the best experience.
This orange and teal interface is designed to help you examine data from different sources, such as:
  • security camera descriptions,
  • suspect interview transcripts, and
  • police reports.
There will be a short quiz after your investigation to check your understanding.

Also, try searching for 'orange' to find the answer to a question.
